citation.article-title: Sphingobacterium antarcticus sp. nov., a Psychrotrophic Bacterium from the Soils of Schirmacher Oasis, Antarctica

p.s: Description of Sphingobacterium antarcticus sp. nov.
Sphingobacterium antarcticus (ānt.ārk'ti.kūs. N .L. antarcticus, pertaining to the antarctic)
Cells are aerobic gram-negative rods, length 2 to 3 μm, width 0.5 to 1 μm.
Colony morphology on peptone-yeast extract agar: round, yellow, smooth, slightly convex, 1 to 2 mm in diameter.
Optimal growth temperature, 25°C; can grow between 2 and 30°C, but not at temperatures above 30°C.
Grow between pH 6 and 8, with optimum growth at pH 6.9.
NaCl not required for growth; can tolerate up to 0.5 M NaCl.
Utilizes a wide variety of carbon sources and can acidify glucose, lactose, cellobiose, raffinose, and mannose.
Does not produce gas from carbohydrates.
Catalase, oxidase, phosphatase, gelatinase, urease, and β-galactosidase positive.
Tween 20, Tween 80, and esculin are hydrolyzed.
The major fatty acid is C16:1; the long-chain bases of the sphingophospholipid are C16:1, C17:0, and C16:0.
DNA base composition is 39.3 to 40.3 mol% G+C.
Habitat is soil from Schirmacher Oasis, Antarctica.
